Code for Germany
2016 Update

2014

In 2014 we started the program with 13 German cities: Berlin, Hamburg, Munich, Cologne, M√ºnster, Paderborn, Leipzig, Dresden, Chemnitz, Gie√üen, Heilbronn, Stuttgart and Ulm.

 2015

7 more OK Labs were launched in 2015, they are: Bonn, Magdeburg, Jena, Frankfurt, Wuppertal, Karlsruhe and Freiburg.

 2016

This year we welcome the cities and regions Kassel, Erlangen, Hannover, D√ºsseldorf, Ruhr district and Lower Rhine. That makes a total of 25 OK Labs in Germany!

HOURS of CODING

FOCUS

Tech for Refugees

The number of people fleeing war and poverty has increased dramatically in the past two years. This presents new challenges to both politics and civil society in Germany and elsewhere. A safe arrival and a first orientation are still the most urgent issues. The tech community in Germany has quickly taken to the matter. The focus on "Digital Refugee Labs" is an effort to strengthen existing projects, help other NGOs in their digital needs, and provide the necessary infrastructure for civic tech (e.g. open wifi).

Digital Refugee Labs

Collaboration with Wikimedia

This year also marks the start of a new partnership. With workshops on Wikidata and OpenStreetMap, we want to explore open data provided by citizens.

Wikidata Workshop

Public funding

1.2 million for FOSS projects \o/

Prototype Fund

PROJECTS

Air pollution in Stuttgart

‹ ›

Despite efforts of environmental organizations, the European limit for atmospheric particulates is regularly exceeded in Stuttgart. To tackle the problem, the OK Lab developed sensors that collect particulate matter data at home. Self-made devices measure air quality and automatically upload it over the internet. The project has raised enought funds to build 300 devices around the city.



Luftdaten.info

Day Care Fees


This simple app helps calculate monthly day care fees for Potsdam. Instead of navigating a complicted set of laws and regulations, parents merely have to input basic information to get an estimate.

Day Care Calculator

Renovation Costs for Berlin Schools


The Berlin Senate recently presented its estimate for renovating local schools: 5 billion euros. This app shows a detailed breakdown of the costs for the district of Lichtenberg.

Renovating our Schools
